text:
Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Solutions and Strategies

Have groups share their thinking about the different grade levels money raising plans in the Initial Challenge. Discuss the similarities and differences in how to approach profit and loss.

Have teams share their results from thinking about the What If Situations. In looking for general relationships, have students first look at subtraction and see what they need to do to find a related addition equation (i.e., add the opposite of what is being subtracted). Then have students come up with a similar relationship for addition (i.e., subtract the opposite of what is being added). (Language and Portrayal)

Making the Mathematics Explicit

When discussing the Initial Challenge bring out how students are making sense of profit and loss. Bring out how they record their thinking using integers.

Suggested Questions

  • In the Initial Challenge, how does the advertising money impact profit or loss? (Answers will vary but help them to see that this is an expense that must be overcome before a grade level makes a profit.)
  • How does the price for purchasing smoothie bars from a distributor/supplies or a car wash/price or to create a digital recording impact profit or loss? (Answers will vary but help them to see that this is an expense that must be overcome before a grade level makes a profit.)
  • How did you record your thinking for the 6th grade/7th grade or 8th grade fundraising efforts? (Answers will vary.)
An example from one classroom of two different groups and how they recorded their thinking for the 7th grade car wash:

Group 1:

We added all the things that would be expenses before they started washing the cars. We used negative numbers to describe them because it is money they have to pay out before earning anything. $-29.50 +$ -15.25 =$ -44.75.

Then we knew for each car they washed they would earn $8. If they washed 5 cars that would be $40 and if they washed 6 cars it would be $48. So they would need to wash at least 6 cars to pay back the money for the supplies and advertising. After that they would make money.

Group 2:

We started with the -29.50 which was how much the supplies cost. We wrote this to represent washing a car and making money that would help pay for the supplies:

$-29.50 +$ 8 = -21.50. Then we kept adding $8.00 until we got to -$5.50. This happened after washing 3 cars. We couldn’t add another $8.00 without going above 0 so we left that for a minute and looked at the $-15.25 for the advertising. We wrote $ -15.25 + $8.00 = $-7.25. We couldn’t add another $8.00 without going above 0. We still had $-5.50 and $-7.25 to make up for so we added those which was $-12.75. We added another $8.00 which still left $4.75 but that was as much as we could do. So looking over all the $8.00 we added it was 5 with still $-4.75 so we knew they’d have to wash at least 6 cars to start making money.

Help students to make sense of the number sentences written for each fund-raising activity. Help students see the connections between the ways that students write down their thinking. In the classroom that had the above two groups the teacher helped them to see that in both situations they looked at the expenses and how many $8 car washes it would take to offset it.

In the first one the group dealt with all the expenses and then used multiplication/division to decide on how many car washes are needed.

In the second group they looked at the expenses separately and added on a positive amount of money until they paid off all they could.

Have students share their strategies for solving the equations in What If Situation C. Many students will find the answers mentally. Help them to verbalize their thinking and show this work using symbols. It is important for the teacher to take the student thinking and have them or the teacher illustrate it using symbols.

For example, using Equation 6:

On strategy might be stated by a student that he/she just subtracted -4 from 43. The teacher can expand it to write that as using the fact family equivalent equation of 43 - - 4 = n.

Another strategy may be to ‘go to’ zero from -4 is a move of 4 and then ‘go to’ 43 so it is a total of 47.
Another strategy may be to guess and check… guess 40 too low, 50 too high, 45 is closer, 47 works.

• Group the equations below by the value of n. What do you notice?
  • When is addition like subtraction? (When you are adding a negative number)
  • When is subtraction like addition? (When you are subtracting a negative number)

Check for Understanding

Using a Chalk Talk Teaching Strategy put the following prompts on chart paper. Have students walk around and respond to them and comments from their peers using a marker.

  • A positive number plus a negative number is always negative.
  • A negative number minus a negative number is sometimes negative.
  • A positive number minus a negative number is sometimes negative.
  • A negative number plus a negative number is always negative.

Now What Do Students Know

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know questions.

Reflecting on Student Learning

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.

  • What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know Question?
  1. Where did my students get stuck?
  2. What strategies did they use?
  3. What breakthroughs did my students have today?
  • How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?
  • Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this unit? The next unit?
